title: Michael Gove ramps up government's No Deal Brexit preparations
text:
brexit countdown_bg Created with Sketch.

Michael Gove today ramped up the government's preparations for a No Deal Brexit as the chances of an agreement being struck between Britain and the EU appeared to collapse.

Boris Johnson effectively killed off hopes of a Brexit deal this morning after turning down a demand from Angela Merkel for Northern Ireland to stay in the customs union 'forever'.

The early morning phone call - and the subsequent reaction from Donald Tusk who accused Mr Johnson of playing a 'stupid blame game' - seemingly put the UK on course for a chaotic split from Brussels.

Mr Gove then published a 159-page 'No-Deal Readiness Report' spelling out all of the measures the government has undertaken to prepare for a bad break on October 31.

The document sets out in detail the government's belief that the UK will be able to cope with No Deal.

The timing of its publication will be greeted by critics with suspicion given that it came just hours after a disorderly divorce from the bloc appeared to become more likely.

The document outlines the actions ministers have taken to minimise the disruption a No Deal Brexit could cause in areas like food supplies, medical supplies and border control.

Michael Gove, pictured in Downing Street earlier this month, today published the government's latest No Deal Brexit planning documents

It makes clear that the government's preference remains for the UK to leave the EU with a deal and it will 'work to the final hour to achieve one'.

But it stresses that 'we are prepared to leave without a deal in order to respect the referendum result'.

The document acts as a summary of all the moves made by the government to tackle potential No Deal disruption.

Some of the newest measures are in relation to ensuring the continued supply of crucial medicines.

The document reveals that the government is setting up a dedicated 'Support Unit' for medical suppliers.

The unit will be tasked with ensuring that companies in the health sector know exactly which forms they need to fill out to make sure time-sensitive medicines make it through customs quickly.

It also reiterates advice to medical suppliers that in the event of a No Deal Brexit they should 'stockpile products above business as usual levels' with ministers recommending six weeks’ of additional stock.

On the issue of food supplies, the document states there will be 'no overall shortage of food if the UK leaves without a deal' but there could be 'reduced availability and choice of a limited number of short shelf-life fruit and vegetables'.

It also spells out the efforts made by the government to help businesses prepare for a bad break, with HMRC in the process of sending 220,000 companies guidance on the steps they need to take to import and export after the UK has left the EU.

Mr Gove, who has been tasked with making sure the UK is ready for a disorderly split, said the government will be 'candid' about the challenges a No Deal Brexit could present.

‘It is the top priority of this Government, and principal focus of my job, to get ready for Brexit on 31 October with or without a deal,' he said.

'We would prefer to leave with a deal, and continue to work in an energetic and determined way to achieve one, but we must be prepared for all eventualities.

‘This report sets out what will change if we leave without a deal and explains what the government is doing to get ready.

'Significant preparations have been underway for the last three years and these have been accelerated under the Prime Minister’s leadership.

‘At every point, the government will be candid about any further challenges ahead as well as clear-eyed about the opportunities.

'Together, government, businesses and citizens are working so that we will be ready for Brexit on 31 October– and can look forward to the future with certainty and confidence.’

Boris Johnson and Angela Merkel, pictured in Berlin in August, had a furious phone call about Brexit this morning which appears to have a made a No Deal split more likely

In a crunch moment for Brexit negotiations this morning, Mr Johnson and Ms Merkel clashed brutally in a breakfast phone call.

No10 sources said the German Chancellor told the premier that Northern Ireland must remain within the EU's customs union indefinitely.

What is Boris Johnson's five-point plan to scrap the Irish backstop? Single market Northern Ireland would leave the Customs' Union with the rest of the UK but stay in the single market. This would constitute an 'all island regulatory zone' that covers trade of all goods. It would mean no checks between the two nations, because Northern Ireland would still have to follow EU rules. Goods from Britain to Northern Ireland would effectively be managed by a border in the Irish Sea, with checks only in that direction, not the reverse. Stormont Lock The 'all island regulatory zone' will have to be approved by the people of Northern Ireland. This means the Northern Ireland Assembly has the right to veto the zone and could hold a referendum on the matter. Customs checks Customs checks would have to be put in place on trade between Northern and the Republic of Ireland. Most checks would be made using technology, but some would still have to be physical. Cash for Northern Ireland A promise of a 'new deal for Northern Ireland' means ministers putting money aside for Belfast and Dublin to help aide economic development and ensure new measures work. Keeping to the Good Friday agreement Freedom of movement between two countries will remain. New deal would confirm commitment to collobaration between UK and Ireland.

But Mr Johnson retorted that meant a deal was 'essentially impossible, not just now but ever'.

Mr Johnson is adamant that Northern Ireland must leave the customs union at the same time as the rest of the UK.

The phone call represents a potentially major moment in the Brexit process and appears to make a No Deal divorce more likely.

It also raises the prospect of the Tories changing tack in the near future by adopting a position ahead of a potential snap general election of backing a No Deal split as the Conservative Party's preferred option.

A Downing Street source said the call with Ms Merkel - which effectively reads the last rites on hopes for an agreement before a crunch EU summit next week - was a 'clarifying moment'.

'If this represents a new established position then it means a deal is essentially impossible not just now but ever,' the No10 source said.

'It also made clear that they are willing to torpedo the Good Friday Agreement.'

Mr Johnson met his Cabinet for crisis talks after the conversation this morning.

Mr Tusk, the president of the European Council, then tweeted: 'Boris Johnson, what’s at stake is not winning some stupid blame game.

'At stake is the future of Europe and the UK as well as the security and interests of our people. You don’t want a deal, you don’t want an extension, you don’t want to revoke, quo vadis?'

Downing Street had already painted a grim picture of the consequences of rejecting the UK's 'fair and reasonable' blueprint which Mr Johnson submitted to the bloc last week.

One source explosively claimed the government will make clear that any EU country supporting a delay to the October 31 Brexit deadline would be engaging in 'hostile interference' in British politics.

Any hope of cooperation will be 'in the toilet' and the Tories will end all negotiations to fight an election, switching to a policy of leaving the EU immediately without an agreement.

The Tories will win because Parliament and Remainer MPs are 'as popular as the Clap', the source claimed.

'They think now that if there is another delay we will keep coming back with new proposals,' the source told the Spectator.

'This won't happen. We'll either leave with No Deal on 31 October or there will be an election and then we will leave with No Deal.'
description: Michael Gove today ramped up the government's preparations for a No Deal Brexit as the chances of an agreement being struck between Britain and the EU appeared to collapse.
